body:
> Thou shall never break the ability to update Firefox

Totally on board with this one! @biancadanforth and I are working on running all the same perf/correctness tests that normal Firefox features get for the upcoming Tracking Protection study, so I think we could reduce the risk around breaking core Firefox features, especially things like startup/update/ability to use the product.

> Thou shall never make Firefox slower

This I think is not appropriate for experiments like the TP study above, and likely many others - for instance the purpose of the study is to present a new proposed UX and measure how users respond to it, and the tracking protection implementation is necessarily much higher-level than it will be if we go forward with it.

The point here is that we want to measure things like user retention *before* we invest the full engineering effort into this feature, so having some small perf regressions is acceptable in this case. The point though is that we've measured and know exactly how much we're regressing and why, and we'll make sure that's reflected in the intent-to-ship that goes in front of release management.

> Thou shall never reduce retention

Per above I think this is the sort of thing we use experiments to measure... if we ship the TP study and it causes retention to drop then we've done something wrong, and this is very useful data that we'll need to get to the bottom of, before we start even thinking about building out the real feature.
